IncidentAddress.IncAddrComment: BACK RIVER NECK RD/ E HOMBERG AVE

AddressCommonName.CommonPlaceName: 32-40 BACK RIVER NECK RD / 1518-1599 E HOMBERG AVE

IncidentSuppNarrative.NarrativeText:
*This stop was captured on in-car and body worn camera*
DUI #: 23-331
CASE #: 23-MSP-021589
SUSPECT: Poole, 3rd, Charles Nathaniel (U/M DOB: 04/12/1995)
VICTIM: Society
TRAINING, KNOWLEDGE, AND EXPERIENCE:
  • Trained to conduct Standardized Field Sobriety Tests in January, 2018.
  • Graduated the Maryland State Police Training Academy in February, 2018.
  • Assigned to the Maryland State Police Glen Burnie Barrack in February, 2018. 
  • Trained in Advanced Roadside Impaired Driver Enforcement (ARIDE) in March, 2018.
  • Certified as a RADAR/LIDAR operator in November, 2019.
  • Certified as Standardized Field Sobriety Test Instructor in January, 2020.
  • Graduated Basic Criminal Investigators Course in September, 2020.
  • Certified as Drug Recognition Expert (DRE) in June 2021.
  • Certified in National Traffic Incident Management (TIM) in August 2021.
  • Certified as Field Training Trooper (FTT) in March, 2022. 
  • Certified as Drug Recognition Expert (DRE) Instructor in May, 2022.
  • Assigned to the State Police Impaired Driver Reduction Effort (SPIDRE) Team in April, 2023.
  • Distinguished graduate of the University of Maryland DUI Institute Session XV in June, 2023.
  • Conducted over 5,300 traffic stops; 168 criminal investigations; and arrested 168 DUI offenders.
NARRATIVE:
                On June 16, 2023 at approximately 0245 hours, I was on duty and in uniform operating unmarked MSP vehicle P-11. I was on routine patrol in the area of Eastern Boulevard at Old Eastern Avenue, Baltimore County, Maryland, when I observed the suspect vehicle.
PHASE 1: VEHICLE IN MOTION
                As I was approaching the intersection of Eastern Boulevard and Old Eastern Avenue, I observed the suspect vehicle exit the side parking lot of The Avenue Tavern, located at 1829 Eastern Boulevard, Essex, Baltimore County, Maryland. I immediately recognized the vehicle as being the suspect vehicle from a previous DUI the same night, where I had just released the suspect approximately one and a half hours prior (Case #: 23-MSP-021580). The suspect vehicle was also being followed by the same vehicle that had been driven by the sober driver that picked the suspect up from the Barrack. When the driver picked the suspect up from the Barrack, she also picked up two other suspected DUI offenders and I knew she was the only sober driver in the vehicle.
                After seeing the vehicle’s exit the parking lot, I immediately turned onto Old Eastern Avenue and began catching up to the vehicles. As I was approaching the vehicles, the suspect vehicle was in the front and I observed it swerve abruptly to the left on one occasion causing both driver side tires to cross the double yellow center line. As we approached the intersection of Old Eastern Avenue at Back River Neck Road, the suspect vehicle came to a stop in the left lane preparing to turn left onto Back River Neck Road. The vehicle stopped over the white stop line and the entire vehicle was parked in a cross walk. I approached the passenger side of the vehicle while in the right lane and made observations of the driver. I immediately recognized the driver as the suspect from the previous DUI arrest as Charles Nathaniel Poole, 3rd (U/M DOB: 04/12/1995). I then waited for the light to change so I could conduct a traffic stop on the suspect vehicle.
                When the light changed, I activated my emergency equipment and conducted a lawful traffic stop on the suspect vehicle. The vehicle stopped in the right lane near the intersection of Back River Neck Road and E Homberg Avenue, Baltimore County, Maryland. The vehicle was the same vehicle Poole had been operating during the previous arrest, a white Chevrolet Impala bearing Maryland registration 3FH8648.
PHASE 2: PERSONAL CONTACT
                I made a driver side approach to the vehicle and made contact with Poole. This time, Poole was the sole occupant of the vehicle. When I initially approached, Poole did not recognize me until I began to talk to him. When I made my initial contact with Poole, he looked over at me and recognized me after a few seconds and then lowered his head into his hands while shaking his head. Poole was asked to turn his vehicle off and exit.
When I was asking Poole if he understood everything I explained to him during his previous arrest, including that he could not drive, he stated, “I understand. You did. I know. I’m just trying to get home.” Poole went on to state, “I literally live right here,” while pointing down the street and stated, “I have no body.” When I explained to Poole that the purpose of calling for a sober driver to pick him up from the Barrack was to get him home safely and prevent him from driving again. Poole continued to state, “I know,” and claimed he was taking the situation seriously. Poole then began pleading for me to “escort” him home. When I told Poole that I would not do that, he asked, “You’re going to lock me up?”
                While I was speaking with Poole this time, I continued to detect the heavy odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath, his eyes were still glossy, his speech appeared more slurred than previously, his eyes were droopy, and he appeared to be drowsier now that time had progressed.
PHASE 3: PRE-ARREST SCREENING
                Based on the circumstances, Standardized Field Sobriety Tests were not conducted. Standardized Field Sobriety Tests were conducted during the previous incident under case #23-MSP021580, which was approximately 2 hours prior to this arrest.
ARREST
                Based on my observations, and my training, knowledge, and experience as a Maryland State Trooper and Drug Recognition Expert, I placed Poole under arrest for driving while impaired and operating a motor vehicle within 12 hours of being charged with a DUI at approximately 0248 hours. Poole was secured in my vehicle to be transported to the Maryland State Police Golden Ring Barrack for further processing. Poole’s vehicle was secured in the parking lot of the Carroll Fuels gas station at the corner, located at 25 Back River Neck Road, Essex, Baltimore County, Maryland.
                Poole was mostly quiet on the way to the Barrack, but occasionally spoke to again criticize my driving. While on the way to the Barrack, I continued to detect the heavy odor of an alcoholic beverage emitting from his breath and person as it emanated throughout the passenger compartment of my vehicle. We arrived at the Barrack at approximately 0257 hours. Poole was also now showing more of a cavalier and non-chalant attitude as if he did not care and was not taking the situation seriously.
                Poole was escorted to the Barrack DUI processing room where he was again provided a copy of his DR-15 Advice of Rights to follow along as I read the form in its entirety. While I was reading the form this time, Poole kept his copy of the form on the table to his right face up. Poole was sitting back in his chair with his feet stretched out in front of him, his hands in his lap, and was looking down at the floor, not appearing to be following along or paying attention. As I was reading the form, Poole also occasionally interrupted me because he was not happy with how I was reading it even though he had previously requested that I read it rather than have the recording read it for him.
After I finished reading the form, Poole refused to talk and was not providing verbal responses to my questions. Poole was asked several times for a verbal response as to whether or not he understood the form. Poole refused to speak and only responding non-verbally by shaking his head up and down. When I asked Poole if he had any questions, he shook his head non-verbally no, and again non-verbally no when he was asked if he wanted to perform the alcohol concentration test. When Poole was shaking his head no, he was looking at me while smiling and smirking. Poole refused to submit to the alcohol concentration test at approximately 0309 hours. Poole again refused to sign all paperwork. After I turned around with the paperwork, Poole looked directly at my body camera and continued to smile and shake his head. Poole then held up two fingers and touched each finger as if he was counting for some reason. Poole continued to occasionally look over at me, smile, and laugh as I continued working on the remaining paperwork.
After I completed the initial paperwork, the certified intoximeter operator stepped into the room to ask if Poole was taking the test. When I informed him no, Poole asked the operator about his day. When the operator responded and asked Poole how his day was, he stated, “Not too bad. I’ve been through worse.” When the intoximeter operator commented on how he was being charged with two DUI’s, Poole replied, “I have a clean record,” and then shrugged as if he did not care about the two DUI charges.
After completing the initial DUI paperwork, Poole was escorted in the Trooper’s Room to remain with me while I completed the necessary court paperwork for his initial appearance hearing with a District Court Commissioner. While I was working on the paperwork, Poole was initially relaxed and laid back in the chair with his feet crossed, head back, and eyes closed appearing to be sleeping. Poole shifted around in the chair several times and began snoring. After completing the court paperwork and waiting for the commissioner to be ready for the hearing, Poole was secured in a temporary holding cell. When Poole stood up, he was visibly more drowsy and incoherent. Poole was unable to stand up on his own and I had to help him stand up. When Poole did stand up, he was unsteady on his feet and I had to help him walk towards the holding cells. Poole also had more of a flushed, reddish appearance to his face. Poole continued to sleep in the holding cell.
                Poole was brought back into the Trooper’s Room for the initial appearance hearing with the District Court Commissioner for Baltimore County. While waiting for the commissioner to call, Poole went back to sleep by laying his head on the desk to his right and continued sleeping and snoring. The initial appearance hearing was conducted virtually. During the initial appearance hearing, Poole continued to scoff, smirk, and laugh over the charges as the Commissioner advised him of the charges and penalties.
DISPOSITION
                After the initial appearance hearing, Poole was ordered to be held without bond. Poole was provided copies of all related paperwork and then secured back in my vehicle to be transported to the Baltimore County Detention Center in Towson pending a bail review hearing. Poole was released at the detention center at approximately 0630 hours after being charged accordingly and provided copies of all paperwork.
All events occurred in Baltimore County, Maryland.
